details.title: Discrete Rayleigh distribution

p: Dilip Roy did his doctoral work in Management from the Indian Institute of Management, Calcutta. He also obtained the Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of Calcutta. He carried out post-doctoral work in Dalhousie University of Halifax, Canada. He has more than eighty papers to his credit. Foreign outlets of his work include, among others, the Journal of Multivariate Analysis, IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Probability in Engineering and Information Science, & Statistics and Probability Letters of U.S.A., Journal of Applied Probability and Microelectronics and Reliability of U.K., Annals of the Institute of Statistical Mathematics, Yokohama Mathematical Journal and JUSE of Japan and Economic Quality Control of Germany. He has published a book on the Theory of Inference in Statistics (in Bengali). He has also edited two books on Strategic Management (1997) and Environmental Management (1998). UGC, Government of India, has honored him with Research Award during the 9-th plan period. He has also received the coveted “Distinguished Teacher Award” in Statistics and Management for the year 2000 from C.V. Kapur Education Foundation, Delhi.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Bus. Adm., Univ. of Burdwan, India
authors.name: D. Roy

details.abstract: Using a general approach for discretization of continuous life distributions in the univariate & bivariate situations, we have proposed a discrete Rayleigh distribution. This distribution has been examined in detail with respect to two measures of failure rate. Characterization results have also been studied to establish a direct link between the discrete Rayleigh distribution, and its continuous counterpart. This discretization approach not only expands the scope of reliability modeling, but also provides a method for approximating probability integrals arising out of a continuous setting. As an example, the reliability value of a complex system has been approximated. This discrete approximation in a nonnormal setting can be of practical use & importance, as it can replace the much relied upon simulation method. While the replication required is minimal, the degree of accuracy remains reasonable for our suggested method when compared with the simulation method.

context.text: Recently, [1], [2] & [13] have embarked upon different approximation procedures for the determination of system reliability, via discretization of the \$s\$-normal probability law.
For statistical tolerancing, or the evaluation of the reliability of a complex system under a known model, discrete approximation plays an important role [1], [2], [14].

references.title: Statistical tolerancing using a modification of Taguchi's method
references.text: J. R. D'Errico, N. A. Zaino Jr., "Statistical tolerancing using a modification of Taguchi's method", Technometrics, vol. 30, pp. 397-405, 1988.

links.abstract: This paper implements and evaluates a discretizing approach for estimating the reliability of systems for which complex functions define strength or stress and where the derivation of reliability exceed analytic techniques. The discretizing approach predicts system reliability with reasonably high accuracy. Specifically, there is little difference in the accuracy of predictions for three engineering problems when compared to simulation results. The reliability predictions are near the 95% confid...

context.text: IN the field of reliability analysis, much emphasis has been given to modeling through continuous life distributions, as discussed in [4], [7].

references.text: K. C. Kapur, L. R. Lamberson, Reliability in Engineering Design, 1976.

links.abstract: The discrete Weibull distribution is defined to correspond with the Weibull distribution in continuous time. A few properties of the discrete Weibull distribution are discussed.

context.text: An initial attempt was made by [8] to provide a discrete model similar to the Weibull distribution.

references.title: The discrete Weibull distribution
references.text: T. Nagakawa, S. Osaki, "The discrete Weibull distribution", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 24, pp. 300-301, 1975.

context.text: Classification of discrete distributions has been attempted by [9] in the univariate setting, and by [11] in the multivariate setting. [5], [15], & [11] have examined some characterizations of discrete models in the univariate case; [10] established relationships among various reliability measures in the discrete bivariate setting, and characterized the bivariate geometric distribution.

references.title: Classifications of discrete lives
references.text: D. Roy, R. P. Gupta, "Classifications of discrete lives", Micro Electronics and Reliability, vol. 32, pp. 1459-1473, 1992.

context.text: Classification of discrete distributions has been attempted by [9] in the univariate setting, and by [11] in the multivariate setting. [5], [15], & [11] have examined some characterizations of discrete models in the univariate case; [10] established relationships among various reliability measures in the discrete bivariate setting, and characterized the bivariate geometric distribution.
As a result, the geometric distribution, according to [10], can be viewed as a discrete exponential (dExponential) distribution, and satisfies the celebrated Lack of Memory Property.
In this sense, we consider the discrete concentration concept of [10] as an interesting & simple approach, which can generate a discrete life distribution model based on a continuous model.
In place of a moment equalization approach, [13] used a suitably adjusted discrete concentration approach[10].

references.title: Reliability measures in the discrete bivariate set up and related characterization results for a bivariate geometric distribution
references.text: D. Roy, "Reliability measures in the discrete bivariate set up and related characterization results for a bivariate geometric distribution", J. Multivariate Analysis, vol. 46, pp. 362-373, 1993.

context.text: Classification of discrete distributions has been attempted by [9] in the univariate setting, and by [11] in the multivariate setting. [5], [15], & [11] have examined some characterizations of discrete models in the univariate case; [10] established relationships among various reliability measures in the discrete bivariate setting, and characterized the bivariate geometric distribution.

references.title: On classifications of multivariate life distributions in the discrete set-up
references.text: D. Roy, "On classifications of multivariate life distributions in the discrete set-up", Micro Electronics and Reliability, vol. 37, pp. 361-366, 1997.

context.text: In terms of failure rate, \$r(x)\$, & the second rate of failure, \$r ^{\ast } (x)\$, as defined in [12], we may examine the similarity between the dRayleigh distribution & the Rayleigh distribution.

references.title: Stochastic modeling through reliability measures in the discrete case
references.text: D. Roy, R. P. Gupta, "Stochastic modeling through reliability measures in the discrete case", Statistics and Probability Letters, vol. 43, pp. 197-206, 1999.

links.abstract: This paper introduces a new discretizing approach for evaluating reliability of any complex system where analytic methods fail to offer a closed-form solution. Numerical analyses on 4 important engineering items have been used to examine the closeness between the proposed reliability estimators and the simulated values. A comparative study between the discretizing approach of English et al. (1996) and ours indicates that our approach is in no way less efficient. It can also retain TFR, DFR, IFRA...

context.text: Recently, [1], [2] & [13] have embarked upon different approximation procedures for the determination of system reliability, via discretization of the \$s\$-normal probability law.
In place of a moment equalization approach, [13] used a suitably adjusted discrete concentration approach[10].

references.title: A discretizing approach for evaluating reliability of complex systems under stress-strength model
references.text: D. Roy, T. Dasgupta, "A discretizing approach for evaluating reliability of complex systems under stress-strength model", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 50, pp. 145-150, 2001.

context.text: In the last section, we make use of the discretization of the Rayleigh distribution for evaluating reliability of a complex system as an alternative to the simulation method, which, according to [14], plays a limited role in reliability experimentation at the time of product design.
For statistical tolerancing, or the evaluation of the reliability of a complex system under a known model, discrete approximation plays an important role [1], [2], [14].

references.title: Performance analysis design
references.text: G. Taguchi, "Performance analysis design", Int'l Production Research, vol. 16, pp. 521-530, 1978.

context.text: Classification of discrete distributions has been attempted by [9] in the univariate setting, and by [11] in the multivariate setting. [5], [15], & [11] have examined some characterizations of discrete models in the univariate case; [10] established relationships among various reliability measures in the discrete bivariate setting, and characterized the bivariate geometric distribution.

references.title: Hazard function and life distributions in discrete time
references.text: E. Xekalaki, "Hazard function and life distributions in discrete time", Comm. Statist. Theory Methods, vol. 12, pp. 2503-2509, 1983.
